node.title: How do you say ‘Omicron’?
node.alt: Is the name of the new coronavirus variant pronounced “OH-muh-kraan” or “AH-muh-kraan"?
node.description: Unlike Alpha, Beta and Delta, the name of the latest known variant is not as straightforward, with some English speakers offering up diverse pronunciations.
node.content: ["Among the many unknowns surrounding the new coronavirus variant called Omicron, named after the 15th letter of the Greek alphabet, one has stood out to many English speakers: How is it pronounced?", "There is no single, agreed-on English pronunciation, experts say.", "A common British pronunciation, according to Merriam Webster, is \u201cOH-muh-kraan,\u201d with a stress on the first syllable.", "A World Health Organization official, Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove, recently said it that way when announcing that the variant was of concern.", "In the United States, it is often pronounced \u201cAH-muh-kraan,\u201d Merriam Webster says. Less common are \u201cOH-mee-kraan,\u201d as Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain pronounced it this week, or \u201cOH-my-kraan.\u201d", "On the New York Times podcast \u201cThe Daily,\u201d Apoorva Mandavilli, who reports on the coronavirus and its variants, said she was going with \u201cAH-muh-kraan.\u201d", "\u201cI don\u2019t think it really matters that much, honestly,\u201d she said.", "The New Oxford English Dictionary gives a pronunciation that differs from those in Merriam-Webster, according to Dr. Andreas Willi, a comparative linguistics professor at Oxford University. \u201cNamely rather like an English phrase \u201co-MIKE-Ron,\u201d he said.", "The word is a compound from the Greek \u201co mikron,\u201d meaning \u201csmall o.\u201d In classical Greek, the word was pronounced with the second syllable sounding like an English \u201cme,\u201d Dr. Willi said.", "\u201cThe question of British versus American pronunciation of the first syllable isn\u2019t really specific to this particular word,\u201d he said. \u201cCompare the British versus American pronunciation of \u201cgod.\u201d", "The divergences are to do with the name having been adopted as a loanword and used by English speakers in different places at different times, Dr. Willi said.", "\u201cWhen we speak of \u2018Paris\u2019 in English, that is also very different from the \u2018proper\u2019 French way of pronouncing the same name,\u201d he said. \u201cBut it is hardly wrong in a strict sense.\u201d"]
